I feel like this is one of those OAs where the judge just really wanted one team to win so discredits a lot of content that comes out from the other
Opp debates this like a nationalisation motion and so runs all the intuitive claims there (inefficiency, government is cash strapped, no incentive to innovate, strikes etc.). Slight problem: this debate isn't about public sector vs private. In P1, we characterise what banning the "for-profit nature" of these companies looks like: passing regulation that prevents them from making a corporational profit that they then generally pass onto owners/shareholders.
This doesn't mean our side has to defend a world where medical care is free and these are charities, just one where companies dont make a profit. So in the same way, electricity and water companies charge you a fee for using electricity and water but don't make an institutional profit, drug production companies and hospitals wouldn't add a profit margin to the cost.
I reiterated this in P2 after O1 but the judge claimed it was a caseshift because apparently we claimed "free healthcare" in P1 which I'm pretty sure we didn't do that was interesting 😂. We did point out that perhaps there would be a slight margin placed on top of the cost that companies would then reinvest into the business to conduct research (as opposed to giving it to shareholders) but this would likely be low for reasons given(I think the intuition pump behind this was the way most non profit unis work - they charge a margin on top of fees that they then use to fund research within department).
But I also felt like the OA ignored a substantial part of the debate aswell: production of medicines + price gouging of medication through exclusive patent rights (so like how Daparim's price went from $13.5 per pill to over $750 when Turing Pharmaceuticals purchased the company) > This felt like a bit of a shame considering this was more what i felt was in the spirit of the motion.
Also FYI- the OA wasn't structured and didn't go through the debate in the form of clashes which would've identified that Opp didn't really have a positive case outside of pieces of mitigation spread across all 3 speeches.
This is probably on the lower end of the OAs ive received but I think that's just a result of a lack of experience in judging + not understanding what not-for-profit organisations are because they don't have to be charities that give things out for free.
I also think wanting to stop the Q&A part of the OA after 3 questions going "I'm sorry I dont want to talk about it anymore and would like to leave" is a bit unfortunate and bad spirited

tournament.motion: TH, as a person of colour witnessing a non-violent crime (petty theft, trespassing, drug possession) by another person of colour in the U.S., would choose to not call the cops.
TH, as a person of colour witnessing a non-violent crime (petty theft, trespassing, drug possession) by another person of colour in the U.S., would choose to not call the cops.
THW ban for-profit organisations from operating in the healthcare sector (e.g., hospitals, drug manufacturing, ambulances etc.)

THP an inquisitorial judicial system over an adversarial judicial system. In the context of this debate, an inquisitorial judicial system is one where the court actively investigates the facts of the case, with judges playing a central role in gathering evidence, questioning witnesses, and examining claims. This system, common in civil law jurisdictions like many European countries, focuses on finding objective truth rather than winning cases. In contrast, an adversarial judicial system, prevalent in common law countries like the United States and United Kingdom, involves opposing parties (prosecution and defense) presenting their arguments and evidence before an impartial judge or jury. In this system, lawyers play a more prominent role, strict procedural rules are followed, and the judge acts primarily as a referee.

TH as Monarawila would assist the British The Kandyan Kingdom was the last independent kingdom in Sri Lanka, having resisted colonial powers for centuries. King Sri Wickramarajasinghe, the last king of kandy faced internal discontent among his nobles and external pressure from the British
You are Monarawila, a regional noble in charge of the Uva Province. You have received a proposition from the British to enter an agreement called the "Kandyan Convention". If the agreement is finalized, you, along with 9 other nobles will assist the British in a coup against the king. King Sri Vikrama Rajasinha will be deposed, and British sovereignty will be established over Kandy.

THP a world where god (or gods) are viewed as dystheistic rather than morally infallible Dystheism is the belief that gods exist but are not morally perfect. Dystheism suggests that gods may have negative attributes, engage in morally questionable actions, or be indifferent to human suffering. Just as flawed humans can act virtuously at times, dystheistic gods may still uphold certain virtues such as justice, honor, or mercy in specific contexts, even if inconsistently. Significant e
THR the romanticization of interracial and interfaith relationships in Bollywood

This House Opposes the posthumous publication of works of art that their creators explicitly did not want published (e.g., 'Until August' by Gabriel García Márquez, 'The Trial' by Franz Kafka, or Emily Dickinson's correspondence).

In times of a huge economic recession, THW implement a minimum spend policy A minimum spend policy requires households to spend a designated percentage of their income and/or wealth in a given period of time. This policy applies progressively, and would replace tax either partially or entirely.

THP a world where all individuals have a strong belief in Ubuntu Ubuntu (“I am because we are”) is a philosophical belief that asserts that people's identities should be shaped by, and their obligations should primarily be owed to, their communities.
